user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of process_params:
```c
static int
process_params (int argc, char *const *argv)
{
  int proc_dash_param = ! 0;
  int i;
  for (i = 1; i < argc; ++i)
  {
    /**
     * The currently processed argument
     */
    const char *const p = argv[i];
    const char *const p_next = (argc == (i + 1)) ? NULL : (argv[i + 1]);
    if (NULL == p)
    {
      fprintf (stderr, "The NULL in the parameter number %d. "
               "The error in the C library?\n", i);
      continue;
    }
    else if (0 == p[0])
      continue; /* Empty */
    else if (proc_dash_param && ('-' == p[0]))
    {
      enum PerfRepl_param_result param_res;
      if ('-' == p[1])
      {
        if (0 == p[2])
        {
          proc_dash_param = 0; /* The '--' parameter */
          continue;
        }
        param_res = process_long_param (p + 2, p_next);
      }
      else
        param_res = process_short_params_str (p + 1, p_next);

      if (PERF_RPL_PARAM_ERROR == param_res)
        return PERF_RPL_ERR_CODE_BAD_PARAM;
      if (PERF_RPL_PARAM_STR_PLUS_NEXT == param_res)
        ++i;
      else if (PERF_RPL_PARAM_ONE_CHAR == param_res)
        abort ();
      continue;
    }
    else if (('0' <= p[0]) && ('9' >= p[0]))
    {
      /* Process the port number */
      unsigned int read_port;
      size_t num_digits;
      num_digits = mhd_tool_str_to_uint (p, &read_port);
      if (0 != p[num_digits])
      {
        fprintf (stderr, "Error in specified port number: %s\n", p);
        return PERF_RPL_ERR_CODE_BAD_PARAM;
      }
      else if (65535 < read_port)
      {
        fprintf (stderr, "Wrong port number: %s\n", p);
        return PERF_RPL_ERR_CODE_BAD_PARAM;
      }
      mhd_port = (uint16_t) read_port;
    }
    else
    {
      fprintf (stderr, "Unrecognised parameter: %s\n\n", p);
      return PERF_RPL_ERR_CODE_BAD_PARAM;
    }
  }
  return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragment in this function modifies any function parameter. Specifically:
- argc is only read in the loop condition and in the expression (argc == (i + 1)); it is never assigned to.
- argv is only indexed (argv[i], argv[i + 1]) to read pointer values; there are no assignments to argv or to argv[...] (no argv = ..., no argv[i] = ...).
- The local variables p and p_next are declared as const char *const and are copies of argv elements; pointer arithmetic (p + 1, p + 2) and passing them to other functions does not modify the original argv or its contents.
- The increment ++i modifies the local loop variable i, not a parameter.
- Calls to functions (process_long_param, process_short_params_str, mhd_tool_str_to_uint) receive pointer values but this code does not alter the pointer parameters themselves; any modification of objects they point to would be by those functions, not by this function.
Given the rule (a function parameter shall not be modified; pointer parameters’ targets may be modified but the pointer itself shall not), there are no violations in the provided code fragment.
